This should be a wakeup call to Ohioans. One thing we know for sure is that the overwhelming majority of those in the hospital with COVID-19 are unvaccinated. The COVID-19 vaccines work to help you stay out of the hospital.

Ohio Hospitals are having to make difficult decisions. Some have implemented patient visitation policies; rescheduled elective procedures; have diverted patients to other hospitals; or have had no choice but to go on EMS bypass, where ambulances are routed elsewhere.

Hospitals are being stretched toward capacity not only because of the high numbers of COVID-19 hospitalizations, but also as a result of staffing challenges, particularly among the dedicated workers that have been fighting this virus on the front lines for more than 18 months.

If you have a health emergency – you are suffering stroke symptoms, or are in a car accident, etc., you should of course not hesitate at all and should call 9-1-1 and seek emergency medical treatment.
Or, perhaps, visit a nearby urgent care center, or clinic inside of a pharmacy or grocery store that can help with treating minor illnesses or injuries.

As some hospitals in Ohio reach near, or peak, capacity, we want to remind you that if you have mild routine healthcare concerns, you're encouraged to evaluate your symptoms and call your healthcare provider instead of going to the emergency room.
